dataset.title: Long-term stream chemistry patterns: Small watershed proportional samples in the Andrews Experimental Forest

section.para: Long-term records of streamflow chemistry are based on significant sampling efforts and laboratory analyses and were initiated in 1968. The study examines nutrient outputs via stream runoff in small watersheds. The original objective was to evaluate the significance of nutrient losses from a forest soil-plant system after timber harvest compared to control watersheds, and to examine the nutrient budget for small watersheds. The study has evolved into a general monitoring effort for stream water chemistry. This study is conducted in conjunction with Andrews precipitation chemistry (CP002) and the U.S. National Atmospheric Deposition Program (NADP) (CP001).

additionalInfo.para:
References Citing Data Set:
Fredriksen, R. L. Study Plan--Nutrient cycle of a small watershed in the Douglas-fir region of the western slope of the Cascade range in Oregon. 1967. PNW-FSL-1602-22
Fredriksen, R. L. 1969. A battery powered proportional stream water sampler. Water Resourc. Res. 5(6)1410-1413, illus.
Fredriksen, R. L. 1972. Nutrient budget of a Douglas-fir forest on an experimental watershed in western Oregon. In Proc. Research on Coniferous Forest Ecosystems -A Symposium, Bellingham, Washington. March 23-24, 1972. (Publ. by USDA, For. Serv. Pac. Northwest For. and Range Exp. Stn.).
Grier, C. C., D. W. Cole, C. T. Dyrness, and R. L. Fredriksen. 1974. Nutrient cycling in 37-and 450-year-old Douglas-fir ecosystems. In Integrated research in the coniferous forest biome, Bull. No. 5. R. H. Waring and R. L. Edmonds, eds. Conif. For. Biome, Ecosys. Anal. Stud. US/IBP. p. 21-34.
RELATED REFERENCES: Harr, R. Dennis, and F. Michael McCorison. 1979. Initial effects of clearcut logging on size and timing of peak flows in a small watershed in western Oregon. Water Resources Res. 15(1):90-94.

intellectualRights.para: Welcome to the H. J. Andrews LTER Database. Our intentions are to make our data as freely available as possible (See Data Availability). Our data sets consist of long-term research study data with accompanying documentation (metadata). Spatial and non-spatial data sets are available as well as software and models. We encourage the use of our data sets, but as a professional courtesy we ask that data users read and agree to the terms of our Data Use Agreement. It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists that results in data used in subsequent research. Therefore, Andrews Forest researchers request appropriate citation and acknowledgement for subsequent distribution or publication of any work derived from these data sets. Data users are strongly encouraged to consider consultation, collaboration and/or co-authorship with original investigators.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: H. J. Andrews Experimental Forest, Watersheds 1, 2, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 & Mack Cr. in the Willamette National Forest

address.deliveryPoint: USDA Forest Service ;Pacific NW Research Station ;3200 SW Jefferson Way

section.title: Experimental Design - CF002
section.para:
Monitor long term trends in nutrient output from experimental watersheds using water samples taken proportional to streamflow. Examine changes in nutrient loss before and after logging . Use rain collector samples to monitor inputs in precipitation. Nutrient concentration of elements are based on analyses conducted at the Chemical Cooperative Analytic Laboratory (CCAL) in Corvallis, Oregon. Total yields are calculated based on streamflow (outflow) and precipitation (inflow) totals.>/p>

The H.J.Andrews Experimental Forest comprises the Lookout Creek Basin (6500 ha). Lookout Creek as well as nine smaller watersheds within the basin have gaging stations. The nine sites consist of three sets of paired watershed experiments: WS 1, 2, 3; WS 6, 7, 8; WS 9, 10; and Mack Creek, a larger (600 ha), old-growth watershed. Drainage areas for the paired watersheds range from 9 to 100 ha and elevations range from 460 to 960 m. Watersheds 2, 8, and 9 are forested controls.

Watersheds stream sampling history in the H. J. Andrews Forest:
WS Land-use Period of Water sampling
1 100% clearcut 1963-66, burned 1966, no roads Water Year 2003 to Present
2 Control Water Year 1981 to present
6 9% roaded 1963, 100%CC 1974 Water Year 1972 to 1987, restarted 2003 to present
7 60% Shelterwood Cut 1974, remaining 40% Overstory cut in 1984, thinned 2001 Water Year 1972 to 1987, restarted 2002 to present
8 Control Water Year 1972 to present
9 Control Water Year 1969 to present
10 100% clearcut 1975, unburned Water Year 1969 to present
Mack Control, 3rd order WS Water Year 1981 to present
See study CP02 for precipitation nutrient analysis.

section.title: Field Methods - CF002
section.para:
Streamwater is sampled from each stream at a rate proportional to the streamflow rate. There are 20 proportions equal to discharge increases of 1/20th of the expected maximum discharge. For each proportional increase, the number of samples taken in the base time period increases by one.

Samples are taken by a battery powered, in-house constructed sampler designed by Richard Fredriksen, study originator. Samples are collected in 5 gal. polyethylene carboys stored in a insulated housing or cabinet. Streamflow is measured continuously with Leopold-Stevens A-35 recorders and Stevens PAT with Campbell CR-10 data logger. The interface between the sampler and the recorders is an array of magnetic reed switches which are activated by magnets attached to the counter weights of the recorders.

Composite samples, taken over periods ranging from 1 to 3 weeks, contain representative sampling of the sediment and dissolved constituents carried by the stream over the collection period Before 1988, samples were collected from the field every three weeks and returned to Corvallis for analysis. During high flow periods the samples were collected at shorter intervals to prevent the carboys from overflowing. Since 1988, stream proportional samples are collected weekly and refrigerated at the Andrews until samples are brought to Corvallis for analysis (every 3 weeks). The individual weekly samples are combined and analyzed as a composite 3-week sample.

Samples are typically combined at the Andrews, but partial samples and other very large samples may be combined proportionally at the lab. All samples are assigned sample type codes. The rules for combining samples and assigning sample type codes were reviewed and are restated as of 10/28/96 by CCAL lab chemist, Cam Jones, as follows:
All three weekly proportional samples for a given watershed sampler, whether partial or full, should be combined for the 3-week period. Any partial collection will cause the sample type designation to be partial ("P") for that entire three week period. Grab samples should be taken when no sample has been collected through the proportional sampler for any single week. Grab samples should be combined with other grab samples and submitted separately to the lab - a carboy could contain one, two or three weekly grab samples. A carboy with three grab samples should be designated as a grab ("G") sample type. Proportional samples with less than 2 liters of water will be augmented AT THE LAB with any grab sample that has been submitted separately and designated as augmented ("A") sample type.

Dates in the data file refer to the end date of a collection period. Data is summarized by water year: October 1 to September 30. Sample type codes note any sample abnormalities resulting from sampler malfunctions or other problems: 1) "P" for partial or incomplete sample, 2) "G" for grab sample taken when sampler inoperative, and 3) "A" for augmented sample when water volume is inadequate, 4) "Y" represents an end-of-year value that is based on the overall concentration of the sampling period, but is not an actual sample.

Quality control samples are taken biannually (one in the winter and one in the summer) at one site each year. Grab samples are taken above and below the station, and two samples are taken through the sampler. One of the through-sampler samples is left at the station and collected with the composite sample the following week. The other through-sampler sample and the grab samples are refrigerated at the Andrews until the composite samples are brought to Corvallis for analysis. Quality control samples undergo the same analysis as the composite samples.

methodStep.instrumentation: 1)Battery powered proportional stream water sampler 2)Streamflow is measured continuously with Leopold-Stevens A-35 recorders and Stevens PAT with Campbell CR-10 data logger.

section.title: Laboratory Methods - CF002
section.para:
Laboratory procedures: ( Descriptions of lab methods are listed in CCAL's Master Procedures Manual)
Note: Diss. Total N values from 6/1/1970-6/21/1971 do not include free ammonia (NH4-N)

Official compilation of water analyses begins with the WY 1969 (10/1/68). The first year, water was stored at 0 degrees C until operation of the PNW-1653 lab in spring, 1969. Originally, samples are analyzed for suspended sediment, alkalinity, pH, ammonia nitrogen, nitrate, nitrite, dissolved organic nitrogen, ortho and total phosphorus, sodium, potassium, calcium, magnesium, and silica. Sulfate was determined for WY 1972 and sulfate and chloride in WY 1979. Aluminum, iron, manganese, and nitrite were below levels of detection and were subsequently dropped from analysis. Analysis of specific conductivity was added in Dec 1974 and total P on an unfiltered sample in Oct 1974. Analysis of total N on an unfiltered sample was started in June 1978. In general, duplicates were run on all analyses until Oct 1983, and are currently conducted randomly. Sulphur and Chloride were analyzed at the University of Washington until 2004, and are now conducted at Oregon State. Dissolved organic carbon was initiated in 2003.

Currently, all samples are filtered upon arrival at the Corvallis lab and pH, alkalinity, conductivity, and autoanalyzer runs (NO3-N, NH4-N, SI) are made immediately. All analyses are completed within 6 weeks. Generally, samples are stored at 0 degrees C if not analyzed immediately.

section.title: Processing Procedures - CF002
section.para: A Visual Foxpro program (pio_fox) combines nutrient concentration data with streamflow to produce outputs in kilogram per hectare by water year, and creates annual nutrient concentrations. This program replaces the original PIO99 Fortran program in March 2005.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Alkalinity as bicarbonate carbon (HCO3-C); method: electrometric titration to pH 4.5
Anion-cation balance: micro equivalence ratio of anions to cations by calculation
Ca, dissolved calcium (filtrable) concentration; method flame aa spectrophotometry
Chloride (dissolved) concentration; method: ion chromatography (automated ferric thiocyanate before 1993)
Doc, dissolved organic carbon concentration; method: combustion
K, dissolved potassium (filtrable) concentration; method flame aa spectrophotometry
Mg, dissolved magnesium (filtrable) concentration; method flame aa spectrophotometry
Na, dissolved sodium (filtrable) concentration; method flame aa spectrophotometry
Ammonia nitrogen (NH3-N) concentration, ammonia as nitrogen; method: automated phenate
NO2-N concentration, nitrite as nitrogen; method: automated diazotization
NO3-N, nitrate + nitrite as nitrogen concentration; method: automated cadmium reduction
Ortho phosphorus concentration, phosphate (PO4-P), reactive phosphorus; method: ascorbic acid finish
Sample volume from streamflow porportional sampler
Streamflow in inches for the period represented by the proportional sample
Silica as silicon concentration; method: automated molybdenum blue
SO4-S (dissolved) concentration, sulfate as sulfur; method ion chromatography (automated barium sulfate before 1993)
Suspended sediment concentration; method: nonfiltrable residue, gravimetric
Total Kjeldahl nitrogen concentration on filtered sample (dissolved); method: kjeldahl digestion H2SO4, CuSO4/KCl, nessler finish
Total phosphorus concentration; method: persulfate/H2SO4 digestion, ascorbic acid finish
Total Kjeldahl nitrogen concentration on unfiltered sample; method: Kjeldahl digestion H2SO4, CuSO4/KCl, nessler finish
Unfiltered total phosphorus concentration; method: persulfate/H2SO4 digestion, ascorbic acid finish
